channel.title: Closed
channel.description:
Well, I have (had) Kubuntu on my computer (dual booting with Windows XP). But I simply can't manage to get my wireless card to work. I'm rather sure it's supported (Dell Wireless WLAN 1370 Mini-PCI card). However, I don't know how to install the drivers for it. I tried using Google but none of the results helped me. I know little about Linux distro's, as I just started trying to use them recently.
So my question is, can someone link me to or give me a simple guide on how to get my wireless card to work? Any help is appreciated.

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

It says that the driver is already installed.

If I try to open the “Windows Wireless Drivers” thing from the K-Menu, it asks for may password and after I enter it, shows up for a second then it goes away.

Nevermind, I’ll just stick with Windows. Thanks anyway guys, someone can lock this.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ok then, open a terminal where your .inf (and all the rest of the driver files) are and type ‘sudo ndiswrapper -i nameofinffile.inf’

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

Well that’s what I thought too, Mopar. But nothing happens no matter what I try.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Schizzo:

I got all of the files and it still doesn’t work. When I go to my K-Menu -> Settings -> Windows Wireless Drivers, nothing happens. It worked the first time but now it doesn’t. Even when I put the command in a terminal with “kdesu” before it, nothing happens. I just get; “X Error: BadDevice, invalid or uninitialized input device 169”. This is really stupid.

That isn’t a problem, it will still show up.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

So, any more advice from anyone?

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

Schizzo:

Yea, I don’t know much of anything at all about Linux distros, as you can probably tell. I just started trying to use them recently. Installing hardware seems to be significantly more complicated than it is in Windows.

Really? Windows needs 50 million drivers for everything. Notice how everything in Linux got auto detected except for your wireless card since the drivers are not open source…

Read full topic

item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

I have no idea what any of that stuff is, or how to use it.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

I have the EXACT same card in my laptop. Trust me, you need to use ndiswrapper and it works. You will probably need to use ifconfig, wlanconfig or wificonfig or something like that and alias the devices and blacklist some other stuff. Trust me, it works, I’ve done it before.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

I got all of the files and it still doesn’t work. When I go to my K-Menu -> Settings -> Windows Wireless Drivers, nothing happens. It worked the first time but now it doesn’t. Even when I put the command in a terminal with “kdesu” before it, nothing happens. I just get; “X Error: BadDevice, invalid or uninitialized input device 169”. This is really stupid.

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You need ALL the files, not just the .inf file, since that is just information and no code.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

Ok, I think I can extract it and upload it. I’ll try that now.

Well I extracted the .inf file and uploaded it, then I downloaded it on Kubuntu. When I selected it to install it, nothing happened. If I try to click on it to install it again, I get the message “Driver is already installed”. But it doesn’t appear in the list of installed drivers, so I can’t configure it or anything.

I’ll just go back to Windows.

Someone can lock this, thanks anyway Mopar.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you driver is an .exe, it basically just has all of the files you need compressed inside of it, so you have to either extract it in windows, extract it with WINE, or you can even upload it and I will extract it for you. Once it is extracted you select the inf file and you are good to go.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

Ok, when I do that, I get a window in which I can choose to install a new driver. It asks me to find the .inf file for it (I’m guessing that’s the file for the driver?). Am I supposed to download the .inf file from somewhere?

I’ve downloaded the .exe file for my driver from the ndiswrapper website, but I’m not sure if I can even use it.

By the way, thanks a lot for all of your help up to this point, I really appreciate it.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Then run ‘kdesu whateverthecommandwas’

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

Lol, I think I restarted out of habit, so used to using Windows.

Anyway, the error message that I got was; X Error: BadDevice, invalid or uninitialized input device 169 (in the konsole window). In a separate error message I got; “Root or sudo privileges required!”.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

There was no need to restart, this isn’t windows you know?

If nothing happens, right click > put into run dialog

That will pop up the command used to start it, now start up Konsole, type that command in and see what the error message is.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

Ok, Mopar, I’ll try to figure out exactly what you just said and do that.

Edit: Well I installed both ndiswrapper and ndisgtk and rebooted. So when I go to my K-menu -> System I see something called “Windows Wireless Drivers” but when I click it, nothing happens.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

With kubuntu, you don’t have to download ndiswrapper. Simply install ndiswrapper and ndisgtk (the graphical front-end) with adept package manager. Then install your windows drivers easily with a graphical front end.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @Schizzo Schizzo
item.description:
@Schizzo wrote:

Ok, well I tried your suggestion, Un-Named, but I don’t understand anything on the page.

Mopar, I’ve downloaded ndiswrapper and I’ve read the directions but I don’t quite understand it either. I’m not exactly sure how to use it.

Read full topic

item.title: Closed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you can’t find a native driver that works, install ndiswrapper and use the windows driver.
